text.0: within the waters runs the moon he with the beauteous wings in heaven.
text.1: ye lightnings with your golden wheels men find not your abidingplace mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.2: surely men crave and gain their wish close to her husband clings the wife.
text.3: and in embraces intertwined both give and take the bliss of love mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.4: o never may that light ye gods fall from its station in the sky.
text.5: neer fail us one like soma sweet the spring of our felicity mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.6: i ask the last of sacrifice as envoy he shall tell it forth.
text.7: where is the ancient law divine who is its new diffuser now mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.8: ye gods who yonder have your home in the three lucid realms of heaven.
text.9: what count ye truth and what untruth where is mine ancient call on you mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.10: what is your firm support of law what varuṇas observant eye.
text.11: how may we pass the wicked on the path of mighty aryaman mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.12: i am the man who sang of old full many a laud when soma flowed.
text.13: yet torturing cares consume me as the wolf assails the thirsty deer mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.14: like rival wives on every side enclosing ribs oppress me sore.
text.15: o Śatakratu biting cares devour me singer of thy praise as rats devour the weavers threads mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.16: where those seven rays are shining thence my home and family extend.
text.17: this tṛta Āptya knoweth well and speaketh out for brotherhood mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.18: may those five bulls which stand on high full in the midst of mighty heaven.
text.19: having together swiftly borne my praises to the gods return mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.20: high in the mid ascent of heaven those birds of beauteous pinion sit.
text.21: back from his path they drive the wolf as he would cross the restless floods mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.22: firm is this newwrought hymn of praise and meet to be told forth o gods.
text.23: the flowing of the floods is law truth is the suns extended light mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.24: worthy of laud o agni is that kinship which thou hast with gods.
text.25: here seat thee like a man most wise bring thou the gods for sacrifice mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.26: here seated manlike as a priest shall wisest agni to the gods.
text.27: speed onward our oblations god among the gods intelligent mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.28: varuṇa makes the holy prayer to him who finds the path we pray.
text.29: he in the heart reveals his thought let sacred worship rise anew mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.30: that pathway of the sun in heaven made to be highly glorified.
text.31: is not to be transgressed o gods o mortals ye behold it not mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.32: tṛta when buried in the well calls on the gods to succour him.
text.33: that call of his bṛhaspati heard and released him from distress mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.34: a ruddy wolf beheld me once as i was faring on my path.
text.35: he like a carpenter whose back is aching crouched and slunk away mark this my woe ye earth and heaven.
text.36: through this our song may we allied with indra with all our heroes conquer in the battle.
text.37: this prayer of ours may varuṇa grant and mitra and aditi and sindhu earth and heaven.
